title: Slavery in the Roman World, 300 B.C.E.–600 C.E.
xlist: Same As: CLSS 836, section 01
description: This class is designed to familiarize students at an advanced level with the scholarship on ancient slavery and its relation to broader historical and sociological debates on the question of human bondage. Since antiquity, the subject has largely been shunned by historians. Only with the rise of the abolitionist movement in the nineteenth century did the question of slavery in the ancient world come to occupy scholarly interest. Debates were then fueled by the rise of Marxist historiography and its engagement with other sociological methods, especially Weberian and Polanyian approaches. With the decline of Marxist states, the subject cooled off in many circles but is now enjoying a return to vogue. The course surveys the major fields of inquiry into Roman slavery as discreet topics using primary and secondary materials, some in original languages. Students gain familiarity by reading and discussing, presenting their findings on a research topic of their choice, and writing up those findings in a research paper.
